reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of integrated water sanitation and hygiene services out of camps aiming at preventing covid - 19 and mitigating negative health outcomes for most vulnerable populations

description.narrative:
Overall, the proposed activities are aiming at contributing to prevent further spread of Covid-19 and to mitigate potential risks related to Health and Hygiene. SI will lead a consortium (WCOC: Wash Consortium out of camps) of 5 NGOs: 3 international: SI, COOPI and FRC and 2 nationals: SEDO and SSORD. By stemming the impact of COVID-19, maintaining to provide WASH support in the frame of the existing humanitarian response plan and addressing Covid-19 response, the WCOC will combine mitigation and prevention in increasingly challenging environments, in Sinjar, Mosul, Baghdad Anbar and Salah al Dine. As lead, SI, thanks to the Consortium Management Unit (CMU), will provide a comprehensive support in capacity building of consortium partners according to activities developed in output 3. This CMU will homogenize, in collaboration with the Wash Cluster, the practices of each partners, especially in the Covid -19 answer ( composition, approaches, monitoring and reporting). The approach of the CMU will benefit from the lessons learned of 18 months of collaboration with partners funded by IHF. This consortium is definitely contributing to the localization agenda both on technical and conformity level.
SI aims at supporting 32,051 individuals living in under-served return areas and in informal settlements in Mosul district to ensure they benefit from sufficient and clean water, live in a dignified and healthy environment while enabling them to have good hygiene practices. The project is specifically designed to focus on helping the HH to adopt the COVID-19 prevention measures and aims at supporting the WASH facilities and good practices in two hospitals in Mosul, Batol hospital (average of 30 to 35 child birth and 200 outpatients /day) and Jamhory hospitals (average of 40 to 50 in-patients and 500 - 800 outpatient daily).
COOPI will provide emergency support to mitigate COVID-19 related risks for 21,000 returnees, IDPs out of camps and in 48 informal settlements in Al-Shirqat (9,449 individuals), Baiji (5,251 individuals) and Al-Hatra (6,300 Individuals). COOPI identified the most critical needs and will respond by repairing WASH services in Baiji Hospital (average of 105 patients daily), rehabilitating water supply and sanitation systems in informal settlements, supporting solid waste management systems in informal settlements and selected hospitals and by increasing availability of hygiene items and awareness within communities. To increase access to safe water supply, sanitation facilities and hygiene items for vulnerable populations in hard to reach areas, FRC will work with IRCS on Sinjar mountain (10,800 individuals) and in Sinuni sub-district (2,694 individuals) by distributing hygiene kits, rehabilitating WASH facilities in 3 health centers (Hardan, Khanasor and Borek Health centers in Sinuni sub-district serving 24,480 individuals) and providing water to informal settlements. SEDO will cover Kirkuk (15,000 individuals in Kirkuk and 12,000 individuals in Hawiga) and Baghdad (2,000 individuals), while SSORD will cover Anbar (3,763 individuals in Ramadi and 12,002 individuals in Falluja) governorates. They will implement Emergency WASH interventions targeting Informal settlements, both in WASH as well as health facilities rehabilitation. SEDO targets the Al Forat General Hospital in Baghdad (2,000 beneficiaries) and 8 health center in Hawija Zaab district (Zaab Tuberculosis Health Care Center, Ghareeb Health Center, Al-Namlah Health Center, Al-Asryah Health Center, Al-Sabaghyah Health Center, Al-Namisah Health Center, Al-Enadyah Health Center and Eterah Health Center) benefiting to 8,400 individuals while SSORD targets 2 Health center in Al Fallujah district (Albu Shijil and AlMustafa health centers having respectively an average of 1606 and 2640 patients/month). Their action will also focus on coordinating with DoWs to promote water quality monitoring and testing and ensure quality and quantities of water.
